bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, October 10, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D. NOV 4 01 DEPT OF STATE.

div1.p: No. 82. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, October 10, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. An unfavorable impression is made in the earnest prosecution of American claims in this County.
No. 82. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, October 10, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to say that not a very favorable impression is being made upon the Liberian Government towards me, in my earnest prosecution of the claims of Miss Winifred Miller, of New Castle, ME; heir of A. M. Miller; Mrs. Ameilia A. Chase of Provincetown Massachusetts, widow of Captain Josiah A. Chase, of the American Schooner "Alice," that burned in this port April 1, 1898, Mrs Emma Parker

Parker of Minneapolis, Minnesota, widow of the late William Parker who did at Robertsports, Liberia Nov. 14, 1900. I have heard of intended actions to be taken, in the way of redress, but this far nothing has been said to me, yet I have very carefully notised their morose actions, since the beginning of these prosecutions.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
